data.title: Rome: Pantheon - Tomb of King Umberto I & Queen Margherita
data.meta_description: On our final morning in Rome, Mike and I paid a visit to the Pantheon (Piazza della Rotonda) before heading to Civitavecchia to board our cruise. A number of chapels, altars, and tombs are interspersed along the Pantheon's interior perimeter. The second exedra chapel on the left houses the Tomb of King Humbert I (Umberto I), second king of Italy, who lived 1844-1900. His wife, Margherita of Savoy (1851-1926), is also entombed here beside him. The chapel and tombs were designed by Giuseppe Sacconi, and completed in 1910 by his student Guido Cirilli after Sacconi's death. Mike took this side-angle photo to show a view of both the king's and queen's tombstones, since the queen's grave marker is hidden behind the altar when viewed from the front. Umberto's tomb features an inscribed alabaster panel mounted in a gilded bronze frame, while Queen Margherita's tombstone is a smaller marble panel below his. The porphyry altar in the center of the chapel (partially visible on the right side of the frame) was created by Cirilli.
data.text:
On our final morning in Rome, Mike and I paid a visit to the Pantheon (Piazza della Rotonda) before heading to Civitavecchia to board our cruise.

A number of chapels, altars, and tombs are interspersed along the Pantheon's interior perimeter. The second exedra chapel on the left houses the Tomb of King Humbert I (Umberto I), second king of Italy, who lived 1844-1900. His wife, Margherita of Savoy (1851-1926), is also entombed here beside him. The chapel and tombs were designed by Giuseppe Sacconi, and completed in 1910 by his student Guido Cirilli after Sacconi's death. Mike took this side-angle photo to show a view of both the king's and queen's tombstones, since the queen's grave marker is hidden behind the altar when viewed from the front. Umberto's tomb features an inscribed alabaster panel mounted in a gilded bronze frame, while Queen Margherita's tombstone is a smaller marble panel below his. The porphyry altar in the center of the chapel (partially visible on the right side of the frame) was created by Cirilli.
